abstracts.cdata!:
This is the project completion report
            (PCR) for the Second Education Project in Guatemala. The
            principal objectives of the project were (a) to continue
            Bank support for pre-vocational secondary education; (b) to
            improve access to education for disadvantaged groups; and
            (c) to improve educational data. These objectives were
            intended to be achieved by constructing and equipping 21
            secondary schools; providing equipment for another eight
            schools; training 700 staff as teachers and administrators;
            financing technical assistance and fellowships and relevant
            studies. The project was adversely affected by the priority
            given to the reconstruction of schools damaged in the 1976
            earthquake, changes in school sites, cumbersome government
            procedures and, on occasion, lack of counterpart funds.
            Lessons learned are as follows; (i) some covenants and
            conditions were over ambitious. The Bank should limit the
            number of covenants to those that are directly related to
            the project and that can be monitored adequately; (ii) there
            were minor problems with technical assistance. However,
            accepting technical assistance from local agencies proved to
            be feasible and cost effective in the Guatemalan context.
            This practice should be encouraged in future projects; (iii)
            education programs were somewhat fragmented in two different
            ministries and there was poor coordination in the technical
            committee under the Ministry of Communications and public
            works. In future education/training projects in Guatemala
            the Bank should verify that the unit in charge of
            implementing the program is adequately staffed, and that the
            coordinating committee has been placed under the
            jurisdiction of the Ministry of Education and has been given
            clear terms of reference before the loan is made; and (iv)
            The scattered placement of buildings on sites resulted in
            high ratios of circulation and covered walkway areas to
            available space. More concentrated arrangements of buildings
            should be sought in future projects.
